medium_description_en: Provides formal diagnostic criteria for gout.
instructions_en: The Acute Gout Diagnosis Rule can help rule in or rule out gout, reducing the need for synovial fluid in highly likely patients and encouraging a broad differential in gout-unlikely patients.

seo.meta_description_en: The ACR/EULAR Gout Classification Criteria aids in classification of likelihood of gout.
seo.keywords_en: acr eular, gout classification, acreular, acr gout, eular gout classification, acr gout classification, gout score, gout algorithm, chronic gout classification, chronic gout prognosis, chronic gout diagnosis

how_to_use.use_case_en: • Patients with mono or oligo-arthritis of unclear etiology where gout is in the differential diagnosis.
how_to_use.pearls_pitfalls_en:
• The ACR/EULAR Classification can be used to formally diagnose gout.
  • The criteria allow for a non-synovium diagnosis of gout (since presence of monosodium urate crystals in a symptomatic joint is the gold standard for gout) to assist clinicians when synovial testing is not possible (small joint, lab testing not available).
how_to_use.why_use_en: • These criteria can substitute for synovial fluid analysis (the gold standard) if fluid analysis is not possible, or if there are sufficient other criteria that the patient meets.

next_steps.advice_en:
• Gout flares are often treated with some combination of steroids, NSAIDS (classically, indomethacin), opioids for extreme pain, and colchicine, depending on a patient's age and other risk factors for complications.
  • After the initial flare, patients may benefit from urate-lowering therapies like allopurinol.
next_steps.management_en: Other causes of monoarthritis should be considered if patient does not meet criteria for gout, for example: pseudogout, septic arthritis, reactive arthritis, psoriatic, rheumatoid, or osteoarthritis.

about.evidence_based_medicine_en:
• These criteria were developed as a consensus by leading gout experts; interestingly, the criteria were reviewed and agreed upon, then weighted and confirmed in a small set of gout patients.
    • These were then included in a validation larger cohort (the Study for Updated Gout Classification Criteria [SUGAR]).
  • The AUC for the ROC for these criteria was 0.95, with a sensitivity of 0.92 and specificity of .89. The clinical-only criteria (without other tests) AUC was 0.89.

Original/Primary Reference.text: Neogi T, et al. 2015 Gout Classification Criteria: An American College of Rheumatology/European League Against Rheumatism Collaborative Initiative. Arthritis & Rheumatology. 20015; 67: 2557–2568. doi: 10.1002/art.39254

Validation.text: Aggarwal R. Distinctions Between Diagnostic and Classification Criteria?. Arthritis Care Res. 2015; 67: 891–897. doi: 10.1002/acr.22583.

creator_info.about_en: Tuhina Neogi, MD, PhD, is an associate professor at Boston University School of Medicine. She is also affiliated with the BUSPH Department of Epidemiology. Dr. Neogi’s research focuses on epidemiology and management of various musculoskeletal/rheumatic diseases, such as osteoarthritis and gout.

input_schema.subheading_instructions: If yes, 7+ Classification Criteria required for positive diagnosis

input_schema.label_en: ≥1 episode of swelling, pain, or tenderness in a peripheral joint/bursa
input_schema.name: entry

input_schema.label_en: Presence of Monosodium Urate (MSU) crystals in a symptomatic joint, bursa, or tophus
input_schema.name: sufficient

input_schema.label_en: Pattern of joint/bursa involvement during episodes
input_schema.name: bursa

options.label: Joint/bursa other than ankle, midfoot or 1st MTP (or involvement in a polyarthritis)
Ankle OR midfoot (as part of monoarticular/oligoarticular episode without 1st MTP)
1st MTP (as part of monoarticular or oligoarticular episode)

input_schema.name: charac
input_schema.tips_en: Erythema overlying joint (reported or observed); can't bear touch or pressure to joint; great difficulty with walking or inability to use joint.

input_schema.label_en: How many episodes with the following time-course?
input_schema.name: time
input_schema.tips_en: ≥2 time course symptoms, regardless of anti-inflammatory use: (1)Time to maximal pain < 24 hours; (2)Resolution of symptoms in ≤14 days; (3)Complete resolution (to baseline level) between symptomatic episodes.

input_schema.name: tophus
input_schema.tips_en: Draining or chalk-like subcutaneous nodule, located in typical locations: joints, ears, olecranon bursae, finger pads, tendons (e.g., Achilles).

input_schema.name: urate
input_schema.tips_en: (Measured by uricase method.) Ideally scored when patient not taking urate-lowering treatment and patient was >4 weeks from an episode. If practical, retest under those conditions. Highest value irrespective of timing should be used.

input_schema.label_en: Synovial fluid analysis of a symptomatic (ever) joint or bursa
input_schema.name: synovial
input_schema.tips_en: Should be assessed by a trained observer.

input_schema.label_en: Imaging evidence of urate deposition in symptomatic joint/bursa
input_schema.name: decomp
input_schema.tips_en: Ultrasound: double-contour sign OR DECT: Demonstrates urate deposition.

input_schema.label_en: Imaging evidence of gout-related joint damage
input_schema.name: imaging
input_schema.tips_en: X-Ray of hands or feet with ≥1 erosion.
